title: Devil's snare
data:
The **devil's snare** is a monster that appears, in slightly different forms, in [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") and [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
- [2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [5 References](#References)

| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | [\[1\]](#cite_note-1)                                      |

In UnNetHack, the Devil's Snare (note capitalization) belongs to the X monster class, which is now defined as "xorns and harmful vegetation".

As in the source (see "Origin"), the Devil's Snare is repelled by bright lights. A flash of light (from an [expensive camera](/wiki/Expensive_camera "Expensive camera") or broken [wand of light](/wiki/Wand_of_light "Wand of light")) will paralyze, harm, and possibly even kill the plant ("The Devil's Snare shrivels"). This hatred of light is similar to [gremlins](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin"). If the plant is holding the player, the flash will force it to release you ("The Devil's Snare falls away from you").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

| A devil's snare:* can [blend in with its surroundings](/wiki/Hide "Hide").
* can [survive underwater](/wiki/Amphibious "Amphibious").
* [does not breathe](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless").
* cannot pick up items.
* has [no eyes](/wiki/Eyeless "Eyeless").
* has no hands.
* has no limbs.
* has no head.
* is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless").
* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is not a valid [polymorphable](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") form.
* is neither male nor female.
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* cannot be [tamed](/wiki/Scroll_of_taming "Scroll of taming").
* [does not move](/wiki/Sessile "Sessile"). |                                                |

In dNetHack, the devil's snare belongs to the new "plant" class of [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster"), which uses the { glyph.

The dNetHack version of the devil's snare is [faster](/wiki/Speed "Speed") than its UnNetHack counterpart and has the added threat of being able to [conceal itself](/wiki/Hide "Hide"). This makes it a sort of living [trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap") that unsuspecting [players](/wiki/Player "Player") can step into.

## Origin

The fictional Devil's Snare comes from the *Harry Potter* series by J. K. Rowling. In the series, the [Devil's Snare](http://harrypotter.wikia.com/wiki/Devil's_Snare) is a sentient plant that attacks those who touch it, by wrapping its vines around them in an attempt to strangle them. It prefers a damp, dark environment and is repelled by fire or bright light, so those caught in Devil's Snare can use spells that produce light or fire to force the plant to release them.

In the book (and adaptations) the Devil's Snare's strangling attack is stimulated by struggling; it is actually possible to escape from the plant simply by relaxing, which causes the plant to release its victim. This feature of the plant does not seem to have been incorporated into any of its NetHack versions.

Interestingly, there is a real plant, [*Datura stramonium*](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datura_stramonium "wikipedia:Datura stramonium"), that is sometimes called "Devil's snare". It is also known as "Jimson weed". It lacks the fictional plant's strangling ability, but it is still dangerous to humans because of its toxicity.

## Encyclopedia entry

"Stop moving!" Hermione ordered them. "I know what this is --  
it's Devil's Snare!"  
"Oh, I'm so glad we know what it's called, that's a great help,"  
snarled Ron, leaning back, trying to stop the plant from curling  
around his neck.  
"Shut up, I'm trying to remember how to kill it!" said Hermione.  
"Well, hurry up, I can't breathe!" Harry gasped, wrestling with  
it as it curled around his chest.  
"Devil's Snare, Devil's Snare . . . what did Professor Sprout  
say? -- it likes the dark and the damp --"  
"So light a fire!" Harry choked.  
"Yes -- of course -- but there's no wood!" Hermione cried,  
wringing her hands.  
"HAVE YOU GONE MAD?" Ron bellowed. "ARE YOU A WITCH OR NOT?"

\[ Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, by J. K. Rowling ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/monst.c in UnNetHack revision 1986, line 3898](http://sourceforge.net/p/unnethack/code/1986/tree/trunk/src/monst.c#l3898)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/uhitm.c in UnNetHack revision 1986, line 2839](http://sourceforge.net/p/unnethack/code/1986/tree/trunk/src/uhitm.c#l2839)
html:
Devil's snare

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

The devil's snare is a monster that appears, in slightly different forms, in UnNetHack and dNetHack.

Contents

  • 1 UnNetHack
  • 2 dNetHack
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry
  • 5 References

UnNetHack

X Devil's Snare (No tile)
Attacks Hug 4d6 drowning
X Devil's Snare (No tile)
Attacks

Hug 4d6 drowning

Base level 14

Speed 10
Base AC 3
Base MR 0
Alignment −2 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 40
Nutritional value 200
Size large
Resistances cold, poison

A Devil's Snare:

  • does not breathe.
  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • never leaves a corpse.
  • cannot be tamed.
  • does not move.
Reference [1]

In UnNetHack, the Devil's Snare (note capitalization) belongs to the X monster class, which is now defined as "xorns and harmful vegetation".

As in the source (see "Origin"), the Devil's Snare is repelled by bright lights. A flash of light (from an expensive camera or broken wand of light) will paralyze, harm, and possibly even kill the plant ("The Devil's Snare shrivels"). This hatred of light is similar to gremlins. If the plant is holding the player, the flash will force it to release you ("The Devil's Snare falls away from you").[2]

dNetHack

{ devil's snare
Difficulty 16
Attacks Claw 4d6 drowning
{ devil's snare
Difficulty 16
Attacks

Claw 4d6 drowning

Base level 14
Base experience 348
Speed 16
Base AC 3
Base MR 0
Alignment −2 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable No
Weight 40
Nutritional value 100
Size large
Resistances cold

A devil's snare:

  • can blend in with its surroundings.
  • can survive underwater.
  • does not breathe.
  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no hands.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • cannot be tamed.
  • does not move.

In dNetHack, the devil's snare belongs to the new "plant" class of monsters, which uses the { glyph.

The dNetHack version of the devil's snare is faster than its UnNetHack counterpart and has the added threat of being able to conceal itself. This makes it a sort of living trap that unsuspecting players can step into.

Origin

The fictional Devil's Snare comes from the Harry Potter series by J. K. Rowling. In the series, the Devil's Snare is a sentient plant that attacks those who touch it, by wrapping its vines around them in an attempt to strangle them. It prefers a damp, dark environment and is repelled by fire or bright light, so those caught in Devil's Snare can use spells that produce light or fire to force the plant to release them.

In the book (and adaptations) the Devil's Snare's strangling attack is stimulated by struggling; it is actually possible to escape from the plant simply by relaxing, which causes the plant to release its victim. This feature of the plant does not seem to have been incorporated into any of its NetHack versions.

Interestingly, there is a real plant, Datura stramonium, that is sometimes called "Devil's snare". It is also known as "Jimson weed". It lacks the fictional plant's strangling ability, but it is still dangerous to humans because of its toxicity.

Encyclopedia entry

"Stop moving!" Hermione ordered them. "I know what this is --
it's Devil's Snare!"
"Oh, I'm so glad we know what it's called, that's a great help,"
snarled Ron, leaning back, trying to stop the plant from curling
around his neck.
"Shut up, I'm trying to remember how to kill it!" said Hermione.
"Well, hurry up, I can't breathe!" Harry gasped, wrestling with
it as it curled around his chest.
"Devil's Snare, Devil's Snare . . . what did Professor Sprout
say? -- it likes the dark and the damp --"
"So light a fire!" Harry choked.
"Yes -- of course -- but there's no wood!" Hermione cried,
wringing her hands.
"HAVE YOU GONE MAD?" Ron bellowed. "ARE YOU A WITCH OR NOT?"

[ Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, by J. K. Rowling ]

The '''devil's snare''' is a monster that appears, in slightly different forms, in [[UnNetHack]] and [[dNetHack]].

In UnNetHack, the Devil's Snare (note capitalization) belongs to the {{white|X}} monster class, which is now defined as "xorns and harmful vegetation".

As in the source (see "Origin"), the Devil's Snare is repelled by bright lights. A flash of light (from an [[expensive camera]] or broken [[wand of light]]) will paralyze, harm, and possibly even kill the plant ("The Devil's Snare shrivels"). This hatred of light is similar to [[gremlin]]s. If the plant is holding the player, the flash will force it to release you ("The Devil's Snare falls away from you").{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2839|unnethack=1986}}
{{clear}}

In dNetHack, the devil's snare belongs to the new "plant" class of [[monster]]s, which uses the {{white|<nowiki>{</nowiki>}} glyph.

The dNetHack version of the devil's snare is [[Speed|faster]] than its UnNetHack counterpart and has the added threat of being able to [[Hide|conceal itself]].  This makes it a sort of living [[trap]] that unsuspecting [[player]]s can step into.
{{clear}}

==Origin==
The fictional Devil's Snare comes from the ''Harry Potter'' series by J. K. Rowling.  In the series, the [http://harrypotter.wikia.com/wiki/Devil's_Snare Devil's Snare] is a sentient plant that attacks those who touch it, by wrapping its vines around them in an attempt to strangle them.  It prefers a damp, dark environment and is repelled by fire or bright light, so those caught in Devil's Snare can use spells that produce light or fire to force the plant to release them.  

In the book (and adaptations) the Devil's Snare's strangling attack is stimulated by struggling; it is actually possible to escape from the plant simply by relaxing, which causes the plant to release its victim.  This feature of the plant does not seem to have been incorporated into any of its NetHack versions.

Interestingly, there is a real plant, [[wikipedia:Datura stramonium|''Datura stramonium'']], that is sometimes called "Devil's snare".  It is also known as "Jimson weed".  It lacks the fictional plant's strangling ability, but it is still dangerous to humans because of its toxicity.

"So light a fire!" Harry choked.
"Yes -- of course -- but there's no wood!" Hermione cried,
